That was Awesome!
Noticed something cool and scary. Before being lit, the gasoline vapors settled to the ground and spread out like water, onto the grass area around the brush pile. You can see fire shoot out into those areas. That is why people get legs burned if they use gasoline and wait too long to light the fire: the vapors have spread out underneath their feet before being ignited.

My conjecture about the group is that they segmented themselves by socioeconomic strata, with the kids who owned the hi-res phones being the ones who appear the most wealthy to the others.

I highly recommend (in the future) that you don't use gasoline to start a fire, it is insanely dangerous.  The gasoline vapor can spread out and travel a substantial distance, I've seen it go 40 ft out from a bonfire, then instantly ignite when it was lit, your visitors were far closer, definitely inside the danger zone.  If you doubt anything I say you can ask any firefighter, they will tell you about how dangerous gasoline is, and recommend kerosene for lighting bonfires.

Nice. The first time I saw this technique was in the mid-90's for a TV ad for a Seattle daily newspaper. I didn't realize at first that it was seeing something I'd never seen before, and longer to work out how it was done.

That footage was pretty rough too, which actually made it easier to figure out how it was done. The Matrix footage was so slick, it was hard to see how it worked. I think, they did a tremendous amount of work in post to fill in in-between frames to make the motion smoother.

You should use a clapper of some kind - like two short lengths of 2x4s and stand where all the cameras can see you - clap the boards together, and you have an audio/visual cue to synchronize the camera views.
You might want to set each camera onto a board stood on end...if all the boards are the same height, you get better alignment as well as some more stability as the camera is supported monopod-style with the board. Gas is dangerous due to vapours - take care!

Also depending on where the sun is in the sky, or where it's setting, and how much sky is visible to each camera pointing in each different direction, the scattered light from the sky will be affecting each camera's white balance before the rocket even takes off. Just try with your own camera rotating 360 degrees around you, or looking slightly up or down through the horizon, the white balance will adjust.

Having same devices for capture will help with white-balancing and stuff, but it may not be enough, since different cameras at different angles will capture different images with different intensity levels, hence the white balancing algorithm may behave differently, making the stitching imperfect. Especially if sudden changes in illumination are expected, such as fire/explosion.

Don't use gasoline ever, did you see how far out the vapors went? In warmer weather you might have set fire to several of your guests. Gasoline is way to volatile. I spent several weeks in a burn ward with a friend of mine who used less fuel than that to start a burn pile, and he was a fireman.

In theory a good idea, but with so many people and their different imperfect reaction times that would still be a few seconds... Wheras, if you clap and look at that on a video editing program, the clap is visualized by a spike, which covers only a fraction of a second. Delete everything before the clap and you have a perfectly timed video sequence with all videos starting exactly at the clap.

Well yes, that's the problem, but what i suggested is the solution for that. If someone claps when everyone already started recording (no matter when they started), you can literally see a common point in all the videos (a spike in the audio track) and you can align it to that point. 
That's what the black and white movie clappers are for that you sometimes see in behind the scenes of hollywood movies.
